column1: Side;Opponent;Round;Number;Attacks;Text

Reviewer 1;Author;1;1;0;Line 156 – the authors refer to “ad-hoc rules” that they have developed for consideration of the different coding transcripts associated with the same spliceogenic variant in variant interpretation and classification.  Although a reference is provided so that the reader can look up what these ad-hoc rules are
column2: it would also be helpful to briefly describe these in the current manuscript.

column1: Reviewer 1;Author;1;2;0;Lines 250-251 and 263-265– In these lines the authors discuss transcripts in which the encoded proteins lack some beta strands.  The lack of these protein structures are used as evidence to support pathogenicity.  It is not clear from the text how lack of these beta strands is predicted to impact protein function.  Is there evidence from another source that these beta strands are critical to protein function and that their loss is deleterious (rather than resulting in normal or slightly reduced protein activity)?
Reviewer 1;Author;1;3;0;Lines 259-274 – This paragraph refers to evidence used in the variant interpretation of three aberrant transcripts that kept the open reading-frame (Δ(E2p3)
column2: Δ(E5) and ▼(E8p3)).  However
column3: the corresponding tables that summarizes variant classification according to the ACMG/AMP-based criteria (Table 2)
column4: does not include these transcript isoform names.  As such
column5: in order to correlate the discussion in this paragraph with the information in table 2
column6: the reader also needs to cross reference Table 1 or 3.  Incorporation of the transcript isoform names in table 2 would assist the reader in correlating this discussion of transcript isoforms with the corresponding evidence used to classify each of the variants.

column1: Reviewer 1;Author;1;4;0;Lines 342-359 – This paragraph discusses two RAD51C variants
column3: for which mg-FL transcripts were detected in 26.3% and 21.3% or transcripts
column4: respectively.  The discussion of these variants in this section (and in other sections) does not address the significance of canonical transcripts in these cases.  Leaky splice variants have been reported in various genes and sometimes can be associated with milder phenotypes (or no phenotypes)
column5: presumably because the canonical isoforms contribute to a “phenotypic rescue”. Is it known whether there is a threshold of RAD51C deficiency that is tolerated before associated cancer risks become increased?

column1: Reviewer 2;Author;1;1;0;"in the Introduction in the sentence 61-69 the authors do not mention anything about BRCA1 (they mention MLH1 though); I would expect that as BRCA1 splice variants are  deeply studied."

column1: “we have developed some ad-hoc rules that take into consideration the coding potential of each individual transcript and its relative contribution to the overall expression to reach the appropriate PVS1_O or BP/_O evidence strength. In brief
column2: for each complex read-out we have applied the following algorithm: (i) De-convolute mgR51C read-outs in-to individual transcripts; (ii) apply ACMG/AMP evidences to each individual transcript; (iii) produce an overall PVS1_O (or BP7_O) code strength based on the relative contribu-tion of individual transcripts/evidences to the overall expression. Thus
column3: if pathogenic supporting transcripts contribute ≥90% to the overall expression
column4: PVS1_O_ code is applied (if different transcripts support different pathogenic evidence strengths
column5: the lowest strength contributing >10% to the overall expression is selected for overall evidence strength). Similarly
column6: BP7_O_ code is applied if benign supporting transcripts contribute ≥90% to the overall expression (if different transcripts support different pathogenic evi-dence strengths
column7: the lowest strength contributing >10% to the overall expression is selected for overall evidence strength). If neither pathogenic nor benign supporting transcripts contribute ≥90% to the overall expression
column8: the splicing assay is considered not providing any evidence in favor

column1: Author;Reviewer 3;2;1;1;"Splicing variants are called solely based on the size difference. It is good to look into Sanger sequence of splice variants after gel elution of the band and sequencing.
Acknowledge this comment.
We have sequenced the RT-PCR products of all variant assays (indicated in Materials and Methods
column2: section 2.5. Minigene Splicing Assays). In fact
column3: all the *.ab1 sequence and*.fsa fragment analysis files of RT-PCR products will be freely available at http://hdl.handle.net/10261/270934; https://doi.org/10.20350/digitalCSIC/14662 upon manuscript acceptance (links indicated in the manuscript section “Data Availability Statement”).

column1: Unfortunately
column2: Sanger sequencing only allowed us to characterize the main transcripts
column3: while the minor ones (<10% of the overall expression) are really difficult to characterize since gel band extraction does not work properly with these small amounts
column4: or other methods (e.g. subcloning of RT-PCR products into a PCR-vector
column5: or RNAseq of minigene outcomes) are laborious and not cost-effective.

column1: Anyway
column2: we have also been using Fluorescent fragment analysis for transcript characterization in our previous studies (since Acedo et al
column3: 2012). We have shown that this technique is highly sensitive
column4: accurate and shows high resolution. For example
column6: transcripts with minimal size differences (1-3 nt) are well-discriminated. So
column7: for minor-rare transcripts is a good option (not perfect
column8: we agree with the reviewer) to annotate them.
